nodes.entity_name: bookrag: a hierarchical structure-aware index-based approach for retrieval-augmented generation on complex documents
nodes.description: "BookRAG: A Hierarchical Structure-Aware Index-Based Approach for Retrieval-Augmented Generation on Complex Documents" is the main title of a research paper that introduces the proposed system "BookRAG," a novel approach for Retrieval-Augmented Generation which leverages hierarchical document structure and indexing for processing complex documents.
nodes.id:
Name: bookrag: a hierarchical structure-aware index-based approach for retrieval-augmented generation on complex documents
Type: SECTION_TITLE

nodes.description: Refers to the target domain or challenge of processing documents with intricate, hierarchical structures, which the BookRAG system is designed to address.

As the initial major section of the paper 'BookRAG: A Hierarchical Structure-aware Index-based Approach for Retrieval-Augmented Generation on Complex Documents', this section provides a concise summary of the research problem, the proposed methodology, and the key findings or contributions of the study.

Retrieval-augmented generation (RAG) is a methodology that combines information retrieval with text generation to improve large language model performance by querying relevant information from external documents, enhancing language models through the retrieval of external domain knowledge for response generation; it serves as a conventional baseline method for document question-answering.

bookindex is a novel index structure and the core indexing component of the BookRAG system, formally defined as a triplet structure for representing document information. It is built by extracting a hierarchical tree from a document and includes both a tree component and a graph component, forming a unified indexing structure. This model supports the structure-aware retrieval of a document's content, with its final representation derived from the entire BookIndex Construction process.
information foraging theory is a theory that inspires the agent based query method in bookrag
nodes.id:
Name: information foraging theory
Type: SCIENTIFIC_THEORY

nodes.description: a hierarchical structure is a property of many real world documents that organizes content at different granularity levels
retrieval recall is a metric on which bookrag's performance is evaluated and serves as the primary evaluation metric being compared among the methods in the table.
qa accuracy is a metric on which bookrag s performance is evaluated
2025 is the publication year of the research paper
artifact availability is a section title in the text
a url pointing to a github repository containing source code  data  and other artifacts
nodes.id:
Name: https github com sam234990 bookrag
Type: SOFTWARE

nodes.description: As the opening section of the paper 'BookRAG: A Hierarchical Structure-aware Index-based Approach for Retrieval-Augmented Generation on Complex Documents', this section introduces the research problem, provides background on Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) for complex documents, and outlines the paper's contributions and structure.
qwen 3 is cited as an example of a large language model
gemini 2 5 is cited as an example of a large language model

The question answering (qa) task is the performance target for large language models (LLMs) that retrieval-augmented generation (RAG) methods aim to boost, and it has been revolutionized by these models. This task, which involves solving complex document-based question-answering problems, is the core focus and evaluation target of the designed RAG system described in the paper.
nodes.id:
Name: question answering (qa) task
Type: TASK_OR_PROBLEM

Type: PUBLICATION_VENUE

nodes.description: Large language models (LLMs) are models whose performance is boosted for question answering tasks, having revolutionized question answering systems. They are used in applications such as text-only RAG, where they generate answers based on retrieved information, and in analyzing content and layout features to determine hierarchical levels and node types, including analyzing title candidates during section filtering. However, they may lack current or domain-specific knowledge.
nodes.id:
Name: large language models (llms)
Type: MODEL_OR_ARCHITECTURE

nodes.description: Figure 1 is an illustration that shows the two paradigms of existing RAG approaches for document-level QA; it is a diagram comparing text-only RAG, layout segmented RAG, and BookRAG for complex document QA, demonstrating their strengths and weaknesses.
A query that is complex in nature, represented by a person icon in the diagram, serving as the initial point in the QA process.
The multi-page document used for QA, depicted as a stack of pages in the diagram.
nodes.id:
Name: complex multi-page document
Type: DOCUMENT

nodes.description: The process of extracting plain text from the document using Optical Character Recognition.
nodes.id:
Name: plain text extraction (ocr)
Type: METHOD_OR_TECHNIQUE

nodes.description: The text chunks that have been extracted and processed without maintaining the document's layout or structure.
The index created from the unstructured text chunks, which can be vector-based, graph-based, or tree-based for retrieval.
The retrieval process that may be fixed or built on a graph structure to obtain relevant texts to the complex query.
A drawback of the text-only RAG in that it doesn't handle dependencies inherent in the document's structure.
nodes.id:
Name: fails on structural dependencies
Type: LIMITATION

nodes.description: This approach first conducts layout analysis and parsing before using a flattened vector index and fixed retrieval.
nodes.id:
Name: layout segmented rag
Type: MODEL_OR_ARCHITECTURE

nodes.description: The indexing of the parsed document in a simplified, linear format to enable quicker retrieval of information.
nodes.id:
Name: flattened vector index
Type: DATA_STRUCTURE

nodes.description: A limit of layout segmented RAG that flattens the data and may lead to loss of complex interrelationships within the document.
nodes.id:
Name: loses complex relationships
Type: LIMITATION

nodes.description: The complex multi-page document converted into hierarchical chunks to preserve the structure's hierarchy.

The agent-based query method, also known as agent-based retrieval, is proposed in BookRAG and is inspired by information foraging theory; it leverages an agent-based system to intelligently extract pertinent information for question answering.
nodes.id:
Name: agent-based query method (agent-based retrieval)
Type: METHOD_OR_TECHNIQUE

nodes.description: The outcome of using the BookRAG approach, producing answers that are accurate and grounded in the document's structure.
ocr  optical character recognition  is a technology used to convert documents into plain text
rag  retrieval augmented generation  is a method used for document level qa  with graph based approaches being state of the art

The image is an icon that depicts a small, open paperback book with a darker cover and several pages, suggesting a book or text-based resource, alongside a separate icon representing photo or visual media content, and it also includes a single circular shape and a color-coded legend that associates different entities and approaches with specific colors.
A graphical representation showcasing a book with an open spine, typically used as an icon or symbol to depict books, reading, or literature.
An icon depicting a photograph or image next to a tabular representation, possibly symbolizing data or information presentation.
An image depicting a tree or a reference to the concept of a tree as suggested by the label 'Tree I'.

An image is a type of content block that serves as a leaf node in the tree component, representing a block of image content, and it is listed as an initial layout-based type for a primitive block, identified during the layout parsing phase.
A geometric shape with a single continuous curved line enclosing an equal amount of space from its center to the edge.

Figure 2 is an image that depicts the BookIndex Construction process, providing an example of bookindex and illustrating the layout parsing phase. It shows Tree Construction from Layout Parsing and Section Filtering, as well as Graph Construction involving KG Construction and Gradient-based Entity Resolution.

Layout analysis & parsing, also known as layout parsing, is a method or technique that analyzes and parses a document's layout to convert complex multi-page documents into a segmented, structured hierarchical tree. This phase processes a document to identify, extract, and organize diverse blocks such as text, tables, images, and titles, creating tree nodes. It is a key step in transforming a raw document into a structured form, as seen in processes like BookIndex Construction, and it identifies blocks like titles without assigning their hierarchical levels.
nodes.id:
Name: layout analysis & parsing (layout parsing)
Type: METHOD_OR_TECHNIQUE

nodes.description: Tree construction is the process of building a hierarchical tree structure from parsed layout data, relying on the analysis of text, titles, tables, and images. As detailed in the paper 'BookRAG: A Hierarchical Structure-aware Index-based Approach for Retrieval-Augmented Generation on Complex Documents', this methodology is a core component of the proposed indexing approach for complex document retrieval.
The method that involves creating a graph using KG Construction followed by Gradient-based Entity Resolution.
The first step in Graph Construction, which involves building a knowledge graph from the tree nodes derived from Layout Parsing.
The second step in Graph Construction, which uses gradient-based techniques to perform entity matching and merging.
nodes.id:
Name: gradient-based entity resolution
Type: METHOD_OR_TECHNIQUE

nodes.description: Representations or components of the document content, visually depicted as individual entities in the graphical description.
A phase for evaluating the similarity and deciding if two entities should match during the gradient-based entity resolution process.
Action taken after successful matching using gradient-based entity resolution to combine or merge related entities.
A label within the section filtering phase that specifies the associated text or content as a method with a font size of 14.
A label indicating experimental content with a font size of 14, presented in the section filtering phase.
The moe layer is a section title with a specified font size of 20 in the section filtering phase and is a title candidate mentioned for analysis by the LLM.

nodes.description: As a subsection of the paper's methodology, this section provides a high-level introduction to the BookIndex component, explaining its purpose and role within the overall BookRAG system for handling complex documents, as detailed in the paper's fourth main section.
nodes.id:
Name: 4.1 overview of bookindex
Type: SECTION_TITLE

nodes.description: A tree structure is part of the bookindex, representing the document's logical hierarchy, and it organizes the document into a hierarchical structure with content blocks as leaf nodes.
a knowledge graph is part of the bookindex  capturing fine grained entities and their relations
t is a variable representing the tree structure component of the bookindex
g is a variable representing the knowledge graph component of the bookindex
m is a variable representing the graph tree link function within the bookindex
n is a variable representing the set of nodes in the tree structure
e t is a variable representing the nesting relationships in the tree structure
v is a variable representing the set of entities in the knowledge graph
e g is a variable representing the set of relations in the knowledge graph
the graph component is composed of entities and relations extracted from document nodes
The graph tree link (gt link) is a mapping function that links entities to tree nodes within the bookindex, serving as a component that connects entities back to their corresponding tree nodes.
nodes.id:
Name: graph tree link (gt link)
Type: MODEL_OR_ARCHITECTURE

nodes.description: entities are extracted from document nodes and are part of the graph component
relations are extracted from document nodes and are part of the graph component
content blocks such as text  tables  and images serve as leaf nodes in the tree component

text is a type of content block that serves as a leaf node in the tree component, representing a block of textual content. It is listed as an initial layout-based type for a primitive block and is identified during the layout parsing phase. Additionally, text can be a final node type that a block can be reclassified as, such as from an erroneous title.
tables are a type of content block that serve as leaf nodes in the tree component
leaf nodes are content blocks nested within section nodes in the tree component
section nodes are part of the hierarchical structure in the tree component  containing leaf nodes
t is a structured hierarchical tree resulting from the transformation of a raw document

Intelligent section filtering is a key step in the document processing pipeline that follows Layout Parsing, where it transforms a raw document into a structured hierarchical tree. This phase processes an initial sequence to identify the document's logically hierarchical structure by analyzing title candidates with an LLM and filtering sections based on specific parameters such as level and type.
nodes.id:
Name: intelligent section filtering
Type: METHOD_OR_TECHNIQUE

nodes.description: The raw document (d) is the initial unstructured input, a collection of pages that is processed during the layout parsing phase and transformed into a structured hierarchical tree.
primitive blocks are defined as a sequence of triplets representing components in a layout based model
Title is a type of block identified during the layout parsing phase, listed as an initial layout-based type for a primitive block, which may be reclassified in the section filtering phase.

A table is listed as an initial layout-based type for a primitive block, representing a node in the tree structure for tabular content and identified as a type of block during the layout parsing phase.
fontsize is a layout feature associated with a primitive block
section is a type of node in the tree structure  representing a hierarchical section with a determined level
method is a title candidate analyzed by the llm and identified as a section node
experiment is a title candidate analyzed by the llm and identified as a section node
fontsize  14 is a parameter associated with the blocks  method  and  experiment
level  2 is a parameter indicating the hierarchical level of identified section nodes
the number 4 is mentioned in the text

A column header categorizing the methods or approaches being compared in the table.
An evaluation metric for the M3DocVQA dataset
nodes.id:

nodes.description: An evaluation metric for the M3DocVQA dataset
An evaluation metric for the MMLongBench dataset

Name: exact match mmlongbench
Type: EVALUATION_METRIC

nodes.description: An evaluation metric for the MMLongBench dataset
The method column is the primary categorical header in the table, listing the different layout-based methods or models being evaluated in the performance comparison.
An evaluation metric for the Qasper dataset
An evaluation metric for the Qasper dataset
m3docvqa is a dataset for document visual question answering, used as a benchmark in performance comparisons and for evaluating retrieval recall performance, where bookrag achieved a recall of 71.2.
mmlongbench is a multimodal long document benchmark dataset used for evaluating retrieval recall performance in comparative assessments.
Qasper is a dataset for question answering on scientific papers, used as a benchmark for evaluating retrieval recall performance and for comparing query efficiency in terms of time and token cost.
The overarching purpose of the table, as stated in the description, to compare the performance of different methods.
BM25 is a conventional RAG baseline method for document QA, using a probabilistic retrieval model and search algorithm for information retrieval, evaluated across multiple datasets.

layout + vanilla is a conventional RAG baseline method for document QA that incorporates layout information, combining Vanilla RAG with layout analysis. It is a layout-based retrieval method that consistently outperforms vanilla RAG by preserving layout information, achieving a recall of 26.3 on document QA benchmarks.
Raptor is a graph-based retrieval-augmented generation (RAG) method designed for document question answering, utilizing an enhanced retrieval-augmented pretraining and fine-tuning approach.

graph based rag (graphrag-local) is a state-of-the-art method for document question answering that uses graph data as an external knowledge source, focusing specifically on local graph structures and retrieval.
nodes.id:
Name: graph based rag (graphrag-local)
Type: METHOD_OR_TECHNIQUE

nodes.description: GraphRAG-global is a graph-based retrieval-augmented generation method for document question answering that focuses on leveraging global graph structures, representing a variant of GraphRAG specifically designed for global graph-based retrieval.

mm-vanilla is a multimodal Vanilla RAG model and a layout-based retrieval method designed for document question answering. It uses layout segmentation for retrieval and has been evaluated on document QA benchmarks, achieving a recall of 7.5.

tree-traverse is a layout-based retrieval method for document question answering that uses a tree traversal approach, applying hierarchical navigation to a tree structure; it was compared for recall on document QA benchmarks, achieving a score of 11.2, but it shows suboptimal results.

docetl is a layout segmented RAG method for document QA, serving as a document extraction and transformation pipeline. It is the strongest baseline to which bookrag is compared, with bookrag reducing token consumption by an order of magnitude.

bookrag is a novel hierarchical structure-aware, index-based model for Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG), designed specifically for documents with a hierarchical layout. It utilizes a unified tree graph bookindex and agent-based planning to maintain the document's structural integrity, enabling precise retrieval and generation. Evaluated on document QA benchmarks, bookrag demonstrates superior performance, achieving the highest recall across datasets, including a score of 57.6 on layout-based tasks, and shows efficiency in terms of query time and token consumption.
exact match is a metric used to measure performance in document question answering
Vanilla RAG is a baseline model used for comparison in retrieval-augmented generation tasks, representing a retrieval-augmented generation model without additional enhancements.

Graphranker is a layout-based retrieval model for document question answering that uses graph-based reasoning and ranking techniques to segment and rank candidate passages. It was evaluated as a baseline method on document QA benchmarks, achieving recall scores of 26.4 and a maximum recall of 44.5, though it has shown suboptimal results in some comparisons.
agent based planning is a technique used by bookrag to configure optimal workflows for query processing, and it is also a method used in bookrag to first classify the query.
nodes.id:
Name: agent based planning
Type: METHOD_OR_TECHNIQUE

nodes.description: A table presenting a retrieval recall comparison among layout-based methods, with the best and second-best results highlighted, as described in the text.
The category of methods being compared in the table, as stated in the description
the selector is a component in bookrag s workflow that narrows the search to a precise information patch
the reasoner is a component in bookrag s workflow that analyzes information after the selector
skyline ranker is a process in bookrag that retains an average number of nodes comparable to a top k setting
71 2  is the recall percentage achieved by bookrag on the m3docvqa dataset
44 5  is the maximum recall percentage achieved by the graphranker baseline
9 87 is the average number of retained nodes after the skyline ranker process on one dataset
6 86 is the average number of retained nodes after the skyline ranker process on another dataset
8 6 is the average number of retained nodes after the skyline ranker process on a third dataset
k   10 is a standard top k setting parameter mentioned for comparison with bookrag s retained nodes

A graph set showing query time and token cost evaluations for different components including MMLongBench. The x-axis indicates 'Query Time' and 'Token cost', while the y-axis represents time in seconds and tokens in millions, respectively.

Query time is an evaluation metric that measures the time taken for queries, displayed in seconds on a bar chart's y-axis, with corresponding values on the x-axis, serving as a comparative metric for assessing query efficiency.

Token cost is a comparative evaluation metric measured in tokens for assessing query efficiency, typically visualized as a bar chart where the x-axis represents different methods or components and the y-axis shows token values in millions.
The entity "time (s)" is a measurement of time in seconds, depicted on the left graph's y-axis, which uses a logarithmic scale; it specifically represents the Query Time on the chart's vertical axis.
The measurement "token (m)" represents millions of tokens and is shown on the vertical y-axis of the right bar chart, where token costs are displayed on a logarithmic scale.
A pair of bar charts showing Query Time (left) and Token cost (right), comparing different methods, including their time in seconds and token costs.

Figure 5 is an image that illustrates the evaluation of efficiency through a comparison chart, showing query efficiency with two metrics: Query Time in seconds and Token cost, depicted through bar graphs under the label 'Qasper'.
graph based rag methods are existing approaches to which bookrag is compared in terms of time and token costs
nodes.id:
Name: graph based rag methods
Type: MODEL_OR_ARCHITECTURE

nodes.description: Text-based RAG approaches, also known as text-only RAG, are methods that involve plain text extraction, unstructured chunks, and fixed or graph retrieval using a vector, graph, or tree structure; these approaches generally have lower latency and token usage because they do not process images.
nodes.id:
Name: text-based rag approaches (text-only rag)
Type: METHOD_OR_TECHNIQUE

nodes.description: multi modal methods are a category of approaches among which bookrag maintains balanced efficiency
nodes.id:
Name: multi modal methods
Type: MODEL_OR_ARCHITECTURE
